A topological space is called totally disconnected if a subset being connected implies that the subset contains at most one point .In other words, a topological space is totally disconnected if its connected components are all the singletons. One checks that a discrete topological space is totally disconnected, and that a product of totally disconnected spaces is totally disconnected, and that being totally disconnected is hereditary. 4 footnote 4 4 footnote 4 Stephen Willard, General Topology, p. 210, §29. Therefore, a profinite ring is compact and totally disconnected. 5 footnote 5 5 footnote 5 In fact, a totally disconnected compact group must be an inverse limit of finite discrete groups: Markus Stroppel, Locally Compact Groups, p. 172.
